case_vignette: A 74-year-old man with a history of type II diabetes and a 40 pack-year smoking history presents to the emergency room complaining of sudden-onset, painless vision loss in his left eye. He describes the feeling as if things went black in his left eye suddenly. His temperature is 98.0°F (36.7°C), blood pressure is 154/94 mmHg, pulse is 100/min, respirations are 17/min, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. Neurological exam reveals cranial nerves III-XII as intact. The patient is unable to see out of his left eye but has normal vision in his right eye. The rest of his exam including strength, sensation, and gait are unremarkable. An ECG is performed as seen in Figure A and an ultrasound of the eye is performed as seen in Figure B. Fundoscopy is performed as seen in Figure C. A CT scan of the head is currently pending.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I suddenly lost vision in my left eye; it's like everything just went black out of nowhere.
Have you experienced any headaches or other neurological symptoms before this vision loss?
No, I haven't had any headaches or other neurological symptoms before this happened.

Is there any history of eye conditions or strokes in your family?

**Final Diagnosis:** Transient Ischemic Optic Neuropathy (TION) or Amaurosis Fugax (AF) (if there's a history of stroke or TIA in the family)

(Note: This diagnosis is based on the given symptoms and does not rule out other possible causes. Further tests, such as an MRI or an angiogram, may be necessary for a definitive diagnosis.)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A new patient arrives at the clinic with sudden vision loss in the left eye. They deny any prior headaches or neurological symptoms before this incident.
trial_0.vignette_mcq: Central retinal artery occlusion. (Figure C shows the typical findings of a central retinal artery occlusion on fundoscopy.)
trial_0.vignette_frq: Based on the given symptoms and exam findings, the most likely diagnosis is Amaurosis Fugax or transient ischemic attack (TIA) of the retina. The painless, sudden-onset vision loss in one eye, intact cranial nerves, and normal neurological exam are consistent with this diagnosis. The ECG and ultrasound findings are not provided in the given information and are not necessary for this diagnosis. The fundoscopy findings would be important to confirm the diagnosis, but they are not shown in Figure C. A TIA is a warning sign for an impending stroke and requires urgent evaluation and management.
trial_0.multiturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or Mini-Stroke (with regard to the sudden onset of vision loss in one eye).
trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA) or Mini-Stroke (with possible involvement of the ocular branch of the posterior cerebral artery).
trial_0.summarized_frq: Based on the given symptoms, the most likely diagnosis is a retinal artery occlusion or transient ischemic attack involving the left occipital lobe. However, further diagnostic tests are necessary for confirmation.

I've suddenly lost vision in my left eye, it just went black out of nowhere.
Have you experienced any headaches or other neurological symptoms along with the vision loss?
No, I haven't had any headaches or other neurological symptoms.

**Final Diagnosis:** Transient Monocular Blindness (if symptoms resolve within an hour), otherwise consider a Retinal Artery Occlusion or other retinal vascular condition. Further evaluation with imaging and specialist consultation is recommended.
